My major research interest is in neurotoxicology, and I have extensive experience with in vitro work with neuronal culture, as well as with in vivo experimental work with rodents. Nature of activity: III. Member of a scientific advisory entity
Organisation: Advisory Committee on Animal Feedingstuffs
Subject matter: Member and deputy chairman of the UK Advisory Committee on Animal Feedingstuffs (ACAF). The Committee provides advice to the UK Government and its Agencies on the safety and use of animal feeds and feeding practices, with particular emphasis on protecting human health and with reference to new technical developments and new feed materials and products. It also addresses animal health aspects and a wide range of contemporary issues including advice on the UK negotiating line on new European Community (EC) proposals, animal feed ingredients including genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and labelling and information for purchasers of animal feed. ACAF is a UK-wide committee made up of independent experts who are appointed for their individual expertise and experience and are not representative of any organisation. The committee is committed to a policy of openness and publishes its agendas, minutes, reports and most of its papers. The recommendations of the committee are agreed after full and open discussions, and there is no voting procedure. Any dissenting opinions are recorded in the minutes of the meeting, which are forwarded to the relevant Government bodies and published on the internet. As a member of ACAF I have not contributed to any publications or recommendations from the Committee that address issues that are dealt with by the CONTAM Panel, although notice is taken in all of the ACAF meetings of Opinions published by EFSA. My term of office ended in September 2011.

Organisation: ADAS UK Ltd
Subject matter: I was employed by ADAS until April 2012. ADAS is a privately- owned company providing environmental services and policy advice to the agricultural industries, regional authorities and the UK Government and its Agencies. It includes risk assessment, but not related to food or feed, nor to contaminants in food or feed. In my employment with the Company I undertook reviews of scientific literature and produced guidance documents on livestock nutrition, feeds and feeding systems. These did not relate to contaminants in livestock feeds, the effects of contaminants on livestock consuming them or on the possible transfer of contaminants into milk, meat or eggs. I was not involved in any research (either public or commercially funded), consultancy or risk assessment nor risk management relating to contaminants in food or feed on behalf of ADAS in the last 5 years. I retired from ADAS in April 2012, and have no full-time involvement with the Company.

Organisation: Food Standards Agency, London, UK. An Executive Agency of the UK Government.

Organisation: ADAS UK Ltd, Wolverhampton, UNITED KINGDOM

Nature of activity: III. Member of a scientific advisory entity
Organisation: Joint WHO/FAO Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA)
Subject matter: Food Additives and Contaminants. The Committee publishes opinions under the aegis of the WHO and FAO on risk assessments for additives and contaminants in food. I have participated in the Committee as both a Member (5 meetings, 2010-14, with voting power, responsible for decisions concerning published opinions) and as a Temporary Expert (14 meetings, 1998-2010, non-voting, responsible for preparing draft documents concerning risk assessments for substances in food). The documents prepared are non-binding opinions of the expert attendees. I have completed numerous dietary exposure assessments for food additives as well as contaminants, including mycotoxins, chloropropanols, methylmercury, perchlorate, and others. I helped develop the Single Portion Exposure Technique (SPET) system for the JECFA procedure for safety assessment of flavouoring substances. I worked as a member of the WHO/FAO update project to renew Environmental Health Criteria (EHC) 70 (now EHC 240), participating in an international workshop in Annapolis MD, USA in May 2005. I am currently invited to participate in the 80th meeting of the JECFA in Rome, June 6-25 2015.

Organisation: US Food and Drug Administration
Subject matter: Food Additives and Contaminants. Group Supervisor, Division of Biotech and GRAS Notification Review (DBGNR). Supervise and mentor members of the Chemistry Group of DBGNR. Duties include the scientific review of GRAS (generally recognized as safe) notifications, the review, comment and sign-off of review documents produced by members of the group, the estimation of exposure to constituents and contaminants in foods, review of GRAS notice summary memoranda and response letters, guidance documents, and draft Federal Register documents. Support Agency (inter-Office) activities, such as recalls and Food Advisory Committees (FAC). Participation in special projects as necessary. Presentations before FDA Food Advisory Committee on olestra, acrylamide, furan, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) from gelatin intake. Advise FDA management on dietary exposure aspects of risk assessments for foods, ingredients, nutients and contamininats. Currently advising on dietary exposure to sodium in the whole diet and caffeine from alcoholic beverages. Re-estimated dietary exposure to acrylamide beginning 2 January 2014, finishing 10 November 2014. Results to appear on FDA website following overall Agency re- evaluation. I do not carry out research as a part of this position and therefore I do not receive private (or public) research funding.

Organisation: Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum (German Cancer Research Center), DKFZ, Heidelberg, Germany, Stiftung des Öffentlichen Rechts der Bundesrepublik Deutschland
Subject matter: Consultancy of projects at the Department of Biostatistics of the German Cancer Research Center which started before end of regular employment in February 2010 and which had not been finished by that time or which were extended by the collaborators afterwards. The number of such ongoing or re-opened projects has been since February 2010 less than five and requires work forf 2-5 meetings per year. The German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ) is a Foundation of Public Law located in Im Neuenheimer Feld 280 | 69120 Heidelberg Germany. The legal remit is to perform research on cancer and described in full detail in https://www.dkfz.de/de/dkfz/download/Satzung.pdf. The expert's role in the organization and his/her main tasks during the employment from 1979 to 2010 was to perform biostatistical research to support the centers remit by in the design and analysis of experimental and clinical studies of the research on cancer. The organisation does not make direkt use of the results of this work, except registering scientific puablication in its reports The work is restricted to give advice in design, evaluation of the data and publication of the results of biomedical studies related to cancer. The organisation has no official responsibility to carry out risk management and is exclusively engaged in the science risk assessment and evaluation related to the incidence and treatment of cancer. The work reported here concerns also Biostatistical research and application of mathematical and statistical methods in the 7th Framework Project BASELINE EU Grant Agreement No 222 738 in a part time contract of 12-34 h/months which ends in 2013 The BASELINE project's objective is to provide harmonised and validated sampling strategies, to support the European policies in food safety and to be suitable for food producers, in order to collect comparable data to improve quantitative risk analysis of selected biological and chemical agents. My work for the project is to support workpackage 6 (WP6) on Model Development by supportimg the WP 6 leader located at the DKFZ in the development of predictive mathematical models for biological risks and investigate and model sources and pathways of chemical contaminants to improve sampling schemes. This is obtained by a review of existing and definition of new mathematical models in predictive microbiology; investigation of correlations between food risk factors and traceable environmental parameters and contamination indicators; consolidation of existing and new models for microbial growth as a function of intrinsic environmental factors and extrinsic parameters. This refers to the previous work for the project done in the function as previous Department Head and previous WP 6 Leader which ended by retirement from the DKFZ in 2010 reported under VI. No provision of advice or services to undertakings, trade associations or other bodies with an interest in the subject matter that falls within EFSA's CONTAM Panel/WG of the CONTAM Panel or related full time emploment at the DKFZ.

Organisation: EU

Organisation: Norwegian Research Foundation NRF
Subject matter: Integrative environmental genomics of cod

Organisation: NERC, Natural Environment Research Council, UK
Subject matter: Development of a new technique for detection of ionic metal and bioavailable trace metals in water. The method of diffusive gradients in thin-films (DGT) emulates some aspects of the dynamics, but it lacks some essential features of the organism. This project introduced controlled biological features into DGT and provided two new tools that can be used in situ to assess bioavailable metals. The biological binding DGT (BBDGT) incorporated cell cultures to enable precise mimicry of uptake from solution. The biological mobilising DGT (BMDGT) contained microbial components that enable the measurement of metals capable of release from colloids and particles.

Organisation: Natural Environment Research Council
Subject matter: Development of a fish gill cell culture system for site-specific water monitoring

Subject matter: Zinc metabolism in pancreatic -cells

Subject matter: Protein-protein interaction between SLC30A8 and PDLIM7 and its influence on Type 2 Diabetes and beta-cell function. This project does not relate to food or the food chain and, therefore, does not fall within the remit of EFSA.

Organisation: BBSRC, Biotechnology and Biological Research Council, Swindon, UK
Subject matter: Regulatory roles of the micronutrient zinc in phosphorylations

Organisation: Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs, South Korea
Subject matter: Development of anti-diabetic functional foods from fermented Korean blueberry. This is a collaboration with Semyung University and a small juice manufacturer (as SME), WellRun, in South Korea. Our task is to identify if fermented blueberry juice causes insulin sensitisation in cultured muscle cells and to investigate the components and mechanisms involved.

Organisation: Norwegian Research Council, Norway, Oslo, Norgesforskningsrådet, NFR.
Subject matter: APREMIA Trace element availability and requirements in salmon. PUBLIC FUNDING The main objectives in this project are 1.to examine if chemical mineral speciation analysis can be used as a predictive measure of apparent mineral digestibility in Atlantic salmon 2.to study mineral bioavailability through examining intestinal routes, rates of uptake and distribution of different chemical forms of minerals in vitro 3.to estimate practical and conditional requirements of Zn, Mn and Se in future feeds for Atlantic salmon, mainly in the seawater phase, based on established and novel biomarkers 4.Based on dietary mineral feed level, digestibility, feed intakes and mineral retentions in feeding trials we will calculate the environmental load of micro minerals in salmon farming under variable farming conditions,and including use of triploid salmon.

Organisation: Johnson & Johnson
Subject matter: ZnT8: From molecular structure to function and back again. This project is about the molecular function of a zinc transporter in pancreatic ß-cells and its role in ß-cell function and type 2 diabetes. The subject matter of this research does not concern food or the food chain and does NOT FALL UNDER THE REMIT OF EFSA. Therefore, I was advised that this grant does not need to be declared. Nevertheless, the funding from this source will amount to less than 21% of my research income for 2015.

Organisation: Frontoffice RIVM/RIKILT Food Safety
Subject matter: Member of a team that writes advices on request of NVWA (Nederlandse Voedsel- en Warenauthoriteit or Netherlands Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority) in the area of environmental contaminants, natural toxins and residues of veterinary drugs and hormones in food and feed. The advices deal with specific contamination of feed or food in order to evaluate whether the contamination presents a risk to animals or humans. For this the exposure is compared with existing health guidance values like those established by EFSA. Advices are prepared by the RIVM (Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu) in cooperation with RIKILT and used by the NVWA to write an advice for the authorities. The work is not related to EFSA opinions and voting on it. I have no role in that process.

Organisation: RIKILT, Institute of Food Safety, NETHERLANDS, Wageningen
Subject matter: RIKILT (not an abbreviation anymore) is privatized and part of Wageningen University and Research. Most work is performed for the Dutch authorities (Ministry of Economics, Agriculture and Innovation). Work for companies is only performed if accepted by the authorities, meaning that there is no conflict of interest. In case of analysis for companies, non-compliant results are reported to the authorities. My current job is programme leader Food Contaminants, dealing with the coordination of a set of projects in the area of environmental contaminants, radionuclides and natural toxins. including the NRL- tasks (National Reference Laboratory) Dioxins and PCB's, Mycotoxins, Marine Toxins, Heavy metals and toxic elements (96/23), PAHs and Pesticides in animal products (96/23). Most of the work is analytical, both method development, validation and analysis. In addition to programme leader I'm project leader in research projects on carry-over studies, development of bioassays for contaminants and Emergency Team Environmental Incidents (BOT-mi). RIKILT has no role in risk management.

Organisation: RIKILT, Institute of Food Safety, NETHERLANDS, Wageningen
Subject matter: RIKILT was asked by Nutreco feed company to provide an independant statement on whether there was a relationship between a dioxin incident with corn (2010) and elevated dioxin levels observed in pigs, based on the observed levels in feed and livers and the congener patterns. Specific knowledge on the kinetics of individual congeners in pigs had to be used, knowledge present at RIKILT. RIKILT had also been involved in the discovery and follow-up of this incident. This work was part of the employment tasks at RIKILT. Furthermore, any activities performed by RIKILT for companies have to be approved first by the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, now Economics, to avoid any conflict of interest with statutory tasks performed by the RIKILT.

Organisation: RIKILT, Institute of Food Safety, NETHERLANDS, Wageningen
Subject matter: I performed a laboratory audit to 3 labs involved in dioxin analysis in Chile. Observations presented in a report. RIKILT was paid by APA (Association of Poultry Producers in Chile); Asprocer (Association of Pork Producers in Chile)

Organisation: RIKILT, Institute of Food Safety, NETHERLANDS, Wageningen
Subject matter: Course on contaminants in feed. In September I adviced SAG on a dioxin incident in Chile with contaminated poultry meat.

Subject matter: Contribution to a report on hazards in feed for the FAO. My role was a chapter on sources and incidents with dioxins, PCBs and flame retardents.

Organisation: Norwegian Scientific Committee for Food Safety
Subject matter: Risk assessment of contaminants in food, as member (and vice-chair) of the panel on contaminants in the Norwegian Scientific Committee for Food Safety (VKM). The activity involves comparing dietary intakes and/or biomarkers of contaminant exposure (e.g. dioxins, dl- PCBs, mercury, flame retardants) in population subgroups with current tolerable intakes. It also involves risk asessment of substances currently without tolerable intakes (e.g. ndl-PCBs, PAHs, furan, oxidation products). VKM also perform risk-benefit assessments. Risk assessments are performed on request from the Norwegian Food Control Authority or is self-initiated by VKM. All panel members have voting rights. The outputs are published as statements or opinions on the official website of the VKM. The delivered advice is taken into concideration by the Norwegian Food Control Authority and other governmental organs.

Organisation: Norwegian Institute of Public Health (Nasjonalt Folkehelseinstitutt), Norway, Oslo
Subject matter: Scientific data collection, experimental studies in mice and cell lines, effects of carcinogens on tumour development and gene expression. Dietary intake assessment of contaminant exposure in population subgroups, and analysis of correlation between dietary intake and biomarkers of exposure. Effets of exposure to organic contaminnats and metals on different end points in the Norwegian birth cohort. The Norwegian Institute of Public Health is not involved in risk managment in the area of food safety.

Organisation: Technical University of Denmark, National Food Institute
Subject matter: The Technical University (DTU) has the following main objectives: education, research, public sector consultancy and innovation. DTU does not participate in development of pesticides in view of their authorisation. DTU does not perform risk management but as stated below we perform research based scientific advising and risk assessment which can be used by the Danish authorities in risk management and decision making. DTU has not developed or published risk assessment guidance or methodologies that are used in the regulatory process of pesticides. For pesticides we use the EFSA PRIMo model for intake calculations and comparison with ADI and ARfD. My main usual tasks are: - Performing research based scientific advising of the National Food Agency about exposure and risk assessment of contaminants and pesticides. - Perform research based advising of the Danish authorities as part of national authorisations for pesticides and before meetings in Codex and EU. - Research within probabilistic modelling. Have been granted access to the programme MCRA (developed by RIVM and Biometris in the Netherlands) so this programme is used for probabilistic calculations. - Teaching at DTU and University of Copenhagen in chemical risk assessment and exposure of contaminants including cumulative and probabilistic modelling. - Teaching in setting maximum limits for contaminants and pesticides. - Preparing Evaluation reports to and MRL proposals for some of the pesticides where Denmark is Rapporteur Member State (RMS). - Preparing evaluation reports for the Northern zone for some of the pesticides where Denmark is RMS. Funding is as a starting point from public money coming from the governmental funding of the University. For some work concerning evaluations of pesticides applicants pay a fee to the authorities and part of this fee is paid to DTU for performing the work. Teaching as part of external projects: - Has done teaching in Chemical Risk Assessment in the EU project Better Training for Safer Food in the period spring 2011 untill now. - Have performed teaching in chemical Risk Assessment in Ghana, Ethiopia and Botswana as part of the EU project EDES from November 2012 to March 2014. The project continues until summer 2015. - Teaching in Chemical Risk Assessment in Saudi Arabia in 2012 as part of an agreement between DTU and the Saudi Arabian authorities. - Teashing in the course arranged and finansed by EFSA "Training seminars on risk assessment for Pre-Accession countries in 2013 - chemical" in July 2013. Payment and funding for external teaching activities mentioned above are paid to DTU.

Subject matter: Part of a granted project about combined exposure to multiole toxic substances (Euromix) within the EU funded research programme Hoizon 2020.

Organisation: The Food and Environment Research Agency
Subject matter: I am employed by Fera. From 1 April 2015, Fera moves from being a wholly-owned agency of UK Government (Defra) to Fera Science Limited, a joint venture between Capita (75% shareholding) and Defra (25% shareholding). This new arrangement means that Fera Science Limited will be legally classified as private sector overall, but will continue to provide independent evidence/advice to UK government as well as commercial services. Following discussions between Fera, FSA with EFSA, it has been agreed that the EFSA Management Board will consider an application from Fera Science Limited for continuation of Article 36 (and so Food Safety Organisation) status, on the grounds that the funding profile for Fera Science Ltd will be dominated by public sector funding, at least in the medium term. EFSA has advised that until the EFSA Management Board reaches a decision in June, Fera Science Limited will retain its current status with EFSA as a Food Safety Organisation, and would not anticipate any consequent changes in the eligibility of Fera staff to serve on EFSA committees. Fera has no official responsibility for food chemical risk management. My own role is to lead a team of scientific staff investigating environmental contaminants in food and their impact on human health. These include dioxins and PCBs (both dioxin-like and non-dioxin-like PCBs), PAHs, trace elements, flame retardants such as PBDEs, TBBPA, HBCDD, organo-phosphorus compounds such as PFOS and the like, brominated and mixed halogenated dioxins, PCNs and other emerging contaminants in foods.

Nature of activity: III. Member of a scientific advisory entity
Organisation: FPS Health, Food chain and Environment, Health Council (CSS), Belgium, Brussels
Subject matter: Member of the Belgian Health Council (Conseil Supérieur de la Santé) - Human Toxicity (Chemical Agents) and various ad-hoc WG concerning Pesticides, biocides, food contaminants, environmental contaminants, chemicals in general. Toxicological evaluations, development of guidance documents (no overlapping with EFSA PPR or CONTAM Panel), advices (preparation of opinions or statements) on health effects of these substances, on guidance documents or on legal documents before adoption. Advices to the Federal Public Service Public Health, Food Chain Safety and Environment, answers to questions from the Minister of Public Health. Expert - invited Member. I participate in my personnal capacity. I do not receive a financial compensation in my individual capacity for the expertise I provided. I have a right to vote. The time devoted to this activity is variable depending on the requests. About 2-6 meetings/year. I am not and was not previously involved in the evaluation of erucic acid in food and feed.

Nature of activity: III. Member of a scientific advisory entity
Organisation: FPS Health, Food chain and Environment (DG4), Belgium, Brussels
Subject matter: Member of the Belgian Registration Committee on Pesticides. Toxicological evaluations (including proposal of classification and labelling of Plant Protection Products and exposure and risk assessment of operator/worker/bystander), preparation of guidance documents and advices on documents from Commission, national and european legal documents, ... No overlapping activity with the PPR Panel. National Authorization of Plant Protection Products. This activity is part of my employment’s tasks. I am officially designated as member of the Registration Committee (representant of the Scientific Institute of Public Health). I do not receive a financial compensation in my individual capacity for the expertise I provided. I have a right to vote (decisions are generally taken by consensus) and a right of veto. About 1 meeting/month. About 20-25% of my time for preparation of reports and attendence to meetings.

Organisation: Scientific Institute of Public Health WIV-ISP - Toxicology Unit, Belgium, Brussels
Subject matter: Head Toxicology Unit since 06/2010. Head of Programme Pesticides - Hazard and Risk Assessment of Pesticides. Management of the activities of expertise and research and development of the Unit. The main research activities of the Unit concern genotoxicity. Toxicological evaluations of chemicals, biocides, food contaminants, ... for other units of WIV-ISP, SPF Public Health, FASFC, Belgian Health Council, EFSA, ... Collaborations with the Unit of Consumer Safety concerning the toxicity of food contact materials. The Institute is a federal public scientific research institute. The Institute has no official responsability to carry out risk management. I am not and was not previously involved in the evaluation of erucic acid in food and feed.
NO INTEREST

Organisation: FASFC & Sci Com- FASFC, Belgian Federal Agency for the Safety of the Food Chain and Scientific Committee of the Federal Agency for the Safety of the Food Chain, BELGIUM, Brussels
Subject matter: At the request of FASFC or its Scientific Committee providence and evaluation of toxicological data on food contaminants or pesticides in the context of the preparation of scientific opinions or advices. I have no right to vote. This activity is considered as part of my employment’s tasks, but I participate in my private capacity. I do not receive a financial compensation in my individual capacity for the expertise I provided. The time devoted to this activity depends on the requests. About 5% of my time. 2-5 meetings/year. In September 2013 I was involved in the preparation of a rapid advice (17-2013) of the Scientific Committee of the FASFC on the presence of perchlorate in leafy vegetables grown in glasshouses. I am not currently involved in the toxicological evaluation or risk assessment of chlorate in food.

Organisation: FPS Health, Food chain and Environment (DG5), Belgium, Brussels
Subject matter: Expert Classification and Labelling Advices on proposals of Classification and Labelling of chemical substances and pesticides. Advices on guidance documents. Mainly scientific support of Belgian RAC (Risk Assessment Committee) member. I have no rights to vote. This activity is part of my employment’s tasks. The time devoted to this activity is variable, depending on the requests, but about 5% of my time. I am not and was not previously involved in the evaluation of erucic acid in food and feed.

Organisation: Scientific Institute of Public Health WIV-ISP, Belgium, Brussels
Subject matter: As Head of the Unit Toxicology, I receive funding from the federal budget for the functionning of the laboratory in order to perform researchs in the field of genotoxicology, biomonitoring and in-vitro toxicology on chemical substances, nanomaterials, non-ionizing radiations and food contact materials. I receive also funding from the Institute in order to engage a PhD and a post Doc on two research projects (one on FCM and one on the use of transcriptomics). “The research (co-)funding I received from the private sector in the latest full budget year, and for the areas covered by the Panels, does not exceeds 25% of the total annual research budget that is managed by me”. This funding concern mainly researchs in the field of non- ionizing radiations.
